descriptions.content:
Like other secondary verbs, ཚར་ occupies the same syntactic position as the modal verbs (after the main verb and before the auxiliary). Apart from its usual meaning of “to finish,” it may also have the adverbial meaning of “already” or “completely,” according to context. When it is used in the first person, the verb may be used without an auxiliary.

  • ཁྲུས་བརྒྱབ་ཚར། “(I’ve) already washed.”
  • ཁྲུས་བརྒྱག་ཚར་སོང་། “(He’s) already washed.”
  • དེ་ནས་ན་ཚ་དྲག་ཚར་བཞག “Then (he) was completely cured.”
  • ཁྱེད་རང་དངོས་ནས་སྨྱོན་ཚར་འདུག་གས། “Have you really gone completely crazy?”

Note: Depending on the context, the adverb “already” may be translated by the auxiliary མྱོང་ (“to have experienced”) or by the auxiliary ཚར་ (“to finish”):

  • ཕྱིན་ཚར། “I’ve already been there (just a while ago, so I don’t need to go again).”
  • འགྲོ་མྱོང་། “I’ve already been there (to India–it’s something I’ve experienced).”
